case_vignette: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive difficulty breathing through his nose and a 2-week history of recurrent severe nosebleeds. When he holds the right nostril shut, he is unable to breathe nasally and his sense of smell is reduced. He has a 6-year history of asthma, which is well controlled with inhaled albuterol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal inspection shows a pink, lobulated mass filling the left nasal cavity. The septum is deviated to the right side. The mass bleeds on touch. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
correct_ans: ct scan of head with contrast

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a hard time breathing through my nose for a month and getting severe nosebleeds for the past two weeks.
Have you been diagnosed with any chronic illnesses or taking long-term medications?
Yes, I have asthma and I use an inhaler to control it.
Is there a history of nosebleeds or bleeding disorders in your family?
I don't know anything about that.
What is your age and sex?
I'm a 13-year-old boy.

Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would suspect this to be a case of Asthma-induced Epistaxis (nosebleeds). However, to confirm, I would need to rule out other causes such as a bleeding disorder. To help with that, I would need to know if there is a history of excessive or recurrent nosebleeds in your family. If not, it is likely that your nosebleeds are related to your asthma.

**Final Diagnosis:** Asthma-induced Epistaxis (if no family history of excessive or recurrent nosebleeds)
